item.title: Put some FEAR in your STALKER 2 with the debris-flinging CinematicFX mod
item.content:encoded:
I’ve long thought of STALKER 2’s gunplay as an underappreciated component of the eerie survival shooter. It’ll never top anyone’s FPS all-timer list but its shootsticks are thunderously bangy, handling with both weight and smoothness, and your own barely-there mortality usually flavours encounters with a delicious high-stakes tension.

The only shortcoming is a lack of visual drama, but that can now be addressed with Cazanu’s new CinematicFX mod: where missed bullets hitting innocent masonry would previously amount to an understated thunk, scenery impacts now throw up vast clouds of dust, smoke, and debris. Cinematic effects, indeed.

I’ve given it a whirl and it works as advertised, imbuing STALKER 2’s action moments with some of the exaggerated wall-ruining flair you’d get from a FEAR, or a Trepang2, or a Black. God, remember Black? Anyway, the mod does well to reflect the specific texture of whatever you’re raking, so while brick buildings erupt into a shower of heavy ships, metal structures flash with gleefully over-egged sparks. I absolutely went around hipfiring at empty buildings just to see what it’d look like, albeit only for a few seconds at a time, quickly running of out ammo on account of it still being STALKER 2.

I also appreciate that this is a relatively small change, as far as STALKER series tweaks go, which to some might seem like I’m tentatively trying Baby’s First Mod. "Urgh, James, why did you never write about STALKER Gamma or Anomaly or any of those other massive mods that make the original games bigger and scarier and more apocalyptic?" Well, smart guy, it’s because I’m a coward. Ever think of that?

item.title: Four years after the last one, Baldur's Gate 1 and 2's enhanced editions have a new patch out in Steam beta
item.content:encoded:
"Yes, you heard that right, nearly 15 years after the Enhanced Editions - and over 25 years since the originals," Beamdog remind us all

Gather round, lovers of classic RPGs. The enhanced editions of the first two Baldur's Gate game, plus Icewind Dale and BG expansion Siege of Dragonspear, have gotten their first patch since 2021. Well, I say gotten, patch 2.7 is only out in Steam beta for now - it'll hit GOG too further down the line.

"We know it’s been a long wait since 2.6 (and for iOS players, since 2.5)," developers Beamdog wrote in their announcement of We’re truly sorry it took this long. With 2026 marking 14 years since BG:EE first launched on PC, we want to thank you for staying with us on this journey."

At this point in these Infinity Engine games' lifespans, Beamdog noted that their main focus is just on keeping things running smoothly as hardware evolves and adding in some handy tweaks where possible. In line with that, patch 2.7 delivers proper Steam cloud saving, by making sure saves can be controlled via Steam's interface, rather than via in-game options menus. Native support for Apple Silicon Macs is another new addition.

Finally, dynamic language support should make it easier from here on out for Beamdog to add new translations to the games without the need for a full patch "on most store fronts". Instead, the developers anticipate being able to drop in new languages "on an ad hoc basis". Speaking of, patch 2.7 adds community-made Brazilian Portuguese, Czech, and Ukrainian translations to Baldur's Gate 2, plus Hungarian and Japanese ones to Icewind Dale.

While you'll have to opt into the Steam beta to enjoy those additions for now, Beamdog have confirmed that the patch'll also be coming to the games' GOG versions on full release. They've also issued some advice for folks looking to avoid have their load orders messed up. "For everyone using mods and worrying about mods, just copy/paste the whole of your game folder in the meantime," they wrote. "This is a beta for now, so you have plenty of time to do that copy. That way, after the live game updates, you'll still be able to launch 2.6 with all your mods."

If this patch has you fancying a return to one of these classic RPGs for the the first time in a while or thinking about trying them for the first time, here are some words you may fancy reading.

item.title: Recovering Helldivers 2 players should check out the cowboy robot gunplay of Far Far West, which has a demo
item.content:encoded:
These robots are magic as well? Leave some tropes for the rest of us, Evil Raptor

If you’ve been holding off playing Helldivers 2 because you’re fervently hoping they’ll eventually add robot cowboy wizards, then firstly, you are eccentric to the point of deranged, and your mother and I are very worried about you, and secondly, why not play the Far Far West demo instead? It’s a one to four player co-op FPS with robot cowboy wizards out the wazoo. Except that robots don’t have wazoos, I think.

Far Far West feels gentler than Helldivers 2, so far, more of a Blazing Saddles-style romp than a Starship Troopers-esque bloodbath. It drops you into a procedurally generated map full of mission objectives and steadily spawning undead.

You will: climb towers to find music discs; unearth graves; activate totems and kill 25 bony buckaroos; endure storms; possibly murder a ghost train; dual-wield; ride a minecart; gather gold; waggle your dukes; drop a nuke.

Just to add to your confusion, the combat puts me a little in mind of Destiny. Aside from dusting upstart skeletons with your clonky gaspunk ordnance, you’ll cast spells by flicking cards and summon a metal horse to ride around on. It’s just as well you don’t have a wazoo, because that metal horse looks like it’d be murder on the ol' nether regions, pilgrim.

There’s the usual progression and cosmetics nonsense between missions, because levelling up is how the West was won. The full game will launch in early access this year. The devs are Evil Raptor, otherwise known for the well-received Akimbot and Pumpkin Jack. The publishers are Fireshine Games, who also brought us Shadows Of Doubt and Reka.

Find the demo on Steam. I can’t think of a cowboy joke to end on. Oh wait, how’s this: if they added support for another two players it’d be a six shooter, ho ho!
